title: Cordless Drill Motor Mount (robot drive system)

description.text: So, it turns out that cordless drill motors make excellent motors to drive larger robots around.  The planetary gearbox gives lots of torque.  These are mounts for the motor used in the Harbor Freight cordless drill Item #68239.  These are often on sale for $15.99.  These run great on a 12V battery, like the one you might put in your next robot.

Buy the cordless drill from Harbor Freight: http://www.harborfreight.com/18-volt-cordless-38-drilldriver-with-keyless-chuck-68239.html There are instructions here on here to lock the clutch mechanism: http://www.wa4dsy.com/robot/drill-motor-hack Print some mounts (OpenSCAD included for any changes needed), get some wheels, and build a robot! The "nut keeper" included can be used to stop a standard nut from loosening if your wheel doesn't thread on directly (The screw in the end is reverse threaded).

author: zapdawg

description.text:
A 5 button hand controller that I used as a wireless controller.

It was redrawn in Onshape so you can copy and edit the files to suit yourself.
https://cad.onshape.com/documents/73b2e99c57989e27f6939f01/w/5c3df88b3e875f22f6024dcf/e/3ad7c2d4a4ec4b6de6b6e7d7
(Except the button mold files, sorry).

It is designed for a 16x2 lcd with or without I2c.
The buttons and pcb mounts are all on a 2.54mm(0.1") pcd for compatability with strip/vero boards.
The buttons I used are: 6x6x5mm through hole, tactile, momentary switch.
The DC power socket is a 2.1mm pcb mount power jack.

I have included button files that can be printed in TPU or molds that can be used for silicon buttons. Both methods work well.

I used an NRF24L01 and an arduino pro mini for this project but an esp8266 or Wemos D1 mini would work as well or better. The choices are endless.

Printer Brand:

Prusa

Printer:

Prusa Steel

Rafts:

No

Resolution:

0.15

Infill:

100

Notes:

I have printed this in both PLA and ABS. Both work.
You can print the case top and bottom either face up with support and a brim for a printed outside texture or face down with no support and a flat face.
If printing face up, I would recommend ABS to make the support easier to remove.

title: Da Vinci AIO and DUO cable chain set

description.text:
i will be modding this again for the y axis cable it seems that there is a real strain in the wire harness that breaks the wires causing a error 30 apparently this is common in xyz printers now that i have had the issue i will not be having it again i will be making a harness for that

these cable chains have ben remixed to flex both ways and a open desighn so you don't have to remove the wires to feed through like the others this is for the AIO and DUO possibly more as i only own a AIO and DUO as a chain that only flexes in one direction binds around the left side of the printer putting pressure on the head and belt

the back bracket has not ben modified just copied from the original creator

these also you put one inside the next outside while installing it on the cable this totally encloses the cable inside the chain

i have added my hot end mount to make a complete set

comments.text: the end lock  is not needed for the AIO but is needed for the DUO as the DUO has a realy heavy plastic  covering the wires and the chain does not interfere with the filament loading arm so the arm that attaches the cable chain  to the carriage is not needed and that end lock replaces that arm

description.text:
This is a battery protector for under slung batteries on quad frames. Designed to specifically fit Turnigy 4S 1300mah packs, but also fits other similarly sized packs. The interior fit is 35mm x 75mm.

I have seen other designs on here, but they are quite thick and bulky, 3mm thick too bulky. This is 0.8mm, and is intended to protect the battery against abrasion and minor bumps while landing and taking off with an under slung battery.

title: Coffee Cup
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This is a fully functional (~8oz) coffee cup. See the Post-Printing section for recommendations on how to heat treat.

Make sure you use a filament that is made from FDA food safe materials (such as ProtoParadigm $5 Filament).

The vertical lines visible in the pictures slightly make it look like the mug has flat sides, however, that is actually the infill. The cup is smooth all the way around.

View it being printed here (turn down speakers if you don't want to hear music) - https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=i5gC_NHcDe8.

Printer Brand:

Rostock

Printer:

Rostock MAX V2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.2

Notes:

The amount of infill is up to you. More infill will result in a heaver cup. You could probably get away without using supports -- the only reason I printed with them is to make sure the arcing spots in the handle turned out.

In order for this cup to be safe to drink out of you'll need to use a filament made from FDA approved material(s) -- such as ProtoParadigm $5 Filament.

You will also need to heat treat it by boiling or baking it. The cup included in the pictures section was heated in a 230F oven for 12 minutes (per ProtoParadigm recommendation). There are several resources online that discuss how to "anneal" PLA to improve it's Heat Deflection Temperature (HDT).

Some warping might occur when heat treating. Based on experience, baking it resulted in less (barely noticeable) warp than boiling.

title: 2006 Chevy Cobalt Manual Transmission Shifter Retainer (Replica)

description.text: The shifter retainer is the most common piece to break in the shifter assembly of the Chevy Cobalt. This is due to the stress riser created at a rib joint near the base which causes the engaging tooth to break. This re-design removes the rib and excess material - leaving only the aligning geometry. Based on the infill you select (45% has been demonstrated to work), you can end up with a higher strength part at a fraction of the weight, with sufficient flexibility to not critically fail on the body of a engaging tooth.

When you have more dresses than dolls, you need to have a way to show them. This print was part of a non-profit, fund-raising project. While there was one Doll, there were many dresses, and they needed to be displayed in a flattering fashion!

The wooden dowels are 5/8" in diameter. If a long dress is to be displayed, only the top half needs to be printed, though both pieces make for a more flattering presentation.

Designed to fit the American Girl series of dolls, there is otherwise no other connection with that brand, express or implied.

Printer Brand:

Prusa

Prusa Steel

Rafts:

No

No

Resolution:

.2mm

Infill:

5%

This part is designed to reduce the wobbling effect that is common to flying extruders on a delta printer.

You can see the difference between a spring, and a damper in this video:
https://youtu.be/pbyXTuhEllA

The STL file that is attached can be used to test the ringing on your printer.

Start with two aluminium tubes. They should telescope inside each other with a sliding fit.
I cut my tubes to be 45mm long.

Drill out the Traxxas ends so that the tube fits snugly inside, and epoxy the tubes into the ends.

Important: You must put a plug of epoxy into the end of the smaller tube. This greatly increases the effectiveness of the damper, and turns the smaller tube into a piston.

Also, use a thin oil lubricant on the parts. Do not use a heavy oil like motor oil, as this will create a perfect seal, and you'll end up with an air spring instead of a damper. You want the air to flow in and out of the gap between the two tubes. Sewing machine oil, or 3-in-1 is perfect for this. Dry lubricant may or may not work, I've tried Ezy-glide but went back to light oil. Graphite powder might work.

comments.text: You could drill a little hole in both tubes at the end so the air won't get compressed in the tubes.
comments.author: Rossini

comments.text: Well, you only need it in the thicker end, and if you do that then you still get oil dripping onto your build plate.  I recommend a dry lube, with no hole.

title: Pioneer Class (Star Trek Online)
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This is the Pioneer Class from Star Trek Online made from scratch, eyeballing some screenshots I took. I believe this is "taller" than the one in game, but I like a standardized saucer because it's easier to keep using that part over and over again and I've always figured Starfleet did the same thing. My thought is that to a Starfleet ship yard, saucers and nacelles are standard. The rest of the stuff is built for the class. Some sources say this, some dispute it. Who knows.

Anyway, this thing is ugly, but it grew on me as I was playing the game. So, I made it while I was taking a break from playing.

description.text: King chess piece

This is an exploding .40 Caliber blow gun dart that explodes on contact with something hard such as brick, asphalt or wood. It is designed to be a humane way to control your backyard pests weather it be birds, squirrels, cats, or that dog that is leaving the cute coily piles in your lawn. It uses a 209 shot shell primer and a standard .177 caliber BB nested in the nose cone. Once the dart is shot at something hard, KAPOW!!! All your backyard pests turn tail! After the smoke clears you are rewarded with a peaceful and quiet back yard. All PLA plastic parts are shredded to pieces during its use and will biodegrade leaving no cleanup. Also included is a non-exploding "inert" dart for target practice! CAUTION: These exploding darts are very loud! Please enjoy with care and consideration for your neighbors and surrounding property. Thingiverse and I DISCLAIM any liability for any damages which may occur during the making and use of these darts. Please follow all local laws and noise ordinances in your area and as always use common sense. Don't give the 3D printing community a bad name!

Things to purchase:
  • Type 209 shot shell primers (found at your local outdoors shop where reloading supplies are sold) A box of 100 is about $3.50-$4.00
  • .177 caliber BB's (sold by the hundreds at any outdoors shop or wal-mart)
    • Instructions:
  • Print (1) of each: Body, retaining ring, and either the Flat point (seems to give more consistent detonations) or round nose cone.
    Printing Profile:
    Layer Height: 0.2mm
    Number of shells: 1
    Infill: 25%
  • Slide retaining ring around the primer
  • Drop BB into the nose cone (it should drop right in and touch the bottom of the recessed hole)
  • Snap the primer and retaining ring onto the nose cone (flash hole of the primer is on opposite side of the BB) the retaining ring should be flush with the back side of the nose cone. There will be play in the primer and retaining ring, this is normal. With the primer pulled out as far as it will go the BB will not fall out of the recessed hole.
  • Slide the nose cone assembly onto the body (it should slide easily but be a snug friction fit). Once assembled it is ready to fire! Caution: Do NOT force the nose cone assembly on the dart body! Extreme pressure on the primer may cause it to go off in your hand! A loose fit can always be solved with glue and is better than a tight one.
  • Once assembled be VERY careful no to drop! To fire hold your .40 cal blowgun at an angle and carefully slide the dart down the muzzle (cone facing toward the muzzle) until it is resting on the mouth piece. If you wish you may also slide the mouth piece of your blowgun off, insert the dart (cone facing toward the muzzle), and replace the mouth piece.
  • FIRE! Stand a minimum of 20 feet from your target. Shoot the dart at something hard i.e.: concrete, asphalt, brick or wood. NEVER NEVER NEVER shoot the dart at any person or anything you do not wish to harm! Be sure to shoot the dart at the highest velocity you can. Too slow of a velocity may result in a undetonated primer. If this happens wait 30 seconds and approach the unexploded dart with caution. If dart is still intact and dry you may attempt to shoot the dart again. If plastic is broken discard the plastic responsibly and you may carefully reuse the primer if it has not been in contact with moisture or oil.
    CAUTION: These darts may damage and/or discolor surface where impacted. Exploding dart may throw plastic and/or metal projectiles back at shooter! ALWAYS stay a minimum of 20 feet from your target when shooting and ALWAYS wear eye protection! Remember you can only lose your eye sight once! Enjoy responsibly and ALWAYS use common sense!

comments.text: I don't know. I'm not familiar with Slic3r but Makerware worked fine. I've not been able to get one to fire yet. I've tried about 10 of them with none of the primers going off. I've only tried the flat nosed version. I tried it with 1 shell at 25% but the nose cone keeps shattering on impact without striking the primer. One or two of primes have a very small dent in them. I'm trying the rounded nose cone at 100% right now. They sure look cool, I can't wait till I get them to work.
comments.author: braintumor2000

comments.text:
I have found that in the R&D of these that if i print with 2 walls it somehow makes the diameter of the dart just a hair larger, requiring to needing shaved down a bit to slide nicely in the blowgun tube so only 1 wall worked well for me. I only have printed these in PLA maybe the softer plastic of ABS cushions just enough to not dent the primer enough? The higher the infill for the cone the better, It will add weight for momentum and will not break before the bb can hit the primer. I have had the best success with the flat head cones with 3 layers for the floor and roof than the round nose (cushion factor i assume). The body is purposely a hair larger than the primer i have measured a few different brands of primers and designed to the higher side of the tolerances. Id hate for someone to press too hard setting the primer in the body and the primer going off (i assume the plastic would break long before the primer would go off.... A drop of super glue works perfect for the trick. Out of all the parts the body can be scaled down 1-2% to fit the primer more snugly...
Be sure to shoot as fast as possible and at the hardest thing possible as well. I have noticed a big difference in shooting at wood vs. concrete or asphalt. Shooting at at a wood fence is probably a %75 success rate where concrete or asphalt is more of a %90 success rate. Once you get your print settings right and you get your first one to pop you'll want to take a picture of the grin on your face! :) Keep us updated on your results! Enjoy!
comments.author: Alpha_Pi_Rho

comments.text: Finally got them to work!!! Very cool indeed! 4 out of the five I made worked me. I got my dad to try them out but he couldn't get his to work. You really do have to blow hard. I used the round nosed one and Makerware for slicing. Setting were: PLA, @210C, 0.2mm layer height, 1 shell and 100% infill on the nose cone (the body was the same but I did 50% infill). I still think (for me at least) I need to decrease the OD and maybe increase the ID of the ring insert. The nose cones fit perfectly in my blowgun util I snap in the insert with the primer. At that point the nose cone bulges out slightly and becomes too wide. I think if I made the insert a little looser around the primer it may also help with having to blow so hard. I'm using Winchester primers btw. Each brand is sightly different so a little tweaking is understandable. Yea the super glue is easy and works great. Like you said it's probably the best way to do it anyhow.  I plan on trying the flat nosed one at 100% next. Thanks for sharing!
comments.author: jasonm621

comments.text: Super cool! Wish i had thought of it!

You are going to need to print the blue_1 part with supports. The yellow_top and yellow_bottom piece might also need supports depending on your printer.

Glue the yellow and blue lid and bottom pieces together (you will need 2x blue_1, 2x blue_2, 1x yellow_top, 1x yellow_bottom)

After assembling the lid and the bottom you can glue the button and the ring to the bottom with the hinge in place as you glue the ring down. Then snap the hinge into the lid.

You will also need 2 magnets (1/4" X 1/16"). Just glue them in place.

Netfabb seems to be gone so these files have not been put through a repair program. I've tested the preview from MakerWare Desktop and it seems like the pieces should print correctly but let me know if you have problems.

Tip: Print your bottom piece (dark blue piece) at a higher in fill percentage, around 40-50% and then all the other parts at 5-10%. That way it will be bottom heavy and not roll around as much.

I had a broken mobile phone charger and I did not have a RAMPS psu. This thing turned the situation around.

I took the circuit board out of the charger, and then there was a lot of hot-gluing steps:

  • hot-glued the board on the inside of the case
  • hot-glued the lid to close it
  • hot-glued the case to the PSU of my Kossel

Now if I don't need the computer to drive the printer, I just plug ramps cable into the USB port.

The measurements are specific to my circuit board: 36x58x20 for the box and 36x58x2.5 for the lid.
The freecad source files are included so it is possible to modify the dimensions if need be.

description.text:
It's Eevee! I'm really pleased with how Eevee came out. I really like the layering of the chest fur and the tip of the tail. It was a little tricky thickening out the eyebrows nose and mouth but I think it turned out well. I've been back lighting these and they look really cool. I think I'm going to start making night light versions!

If you are having trouble with the eyebrows, nose or mouth scaling the model up larger seems to help. Otherwise you might need to get a smaller nozzle tip. I printed this using a 0.4mm nozzle at original scale with no issues.

title: Omnipod Pod Cover - Base Model
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text: This is a cover for the Omnipod Insulin Pump pods. My wife is a type 1 diabetic who uses the omnipod, and I designed these covers for her as a Christmas gift. From her experience using the covers, they add a negligible amount of weight, they don't really add much to the thickness, and they don't fall off. Once done with the pod though, they are easy to remove to use on the next one. I use the base model to make any modifications that I want, hopefully you can come up with some fun things to do with it yourself.

This is designed from a 3D scan. I cleaned up the file in blender, modified the mesh mostly in meshmixer, then did some final work on it in blender. Any design modifications like text or pictures were also done in blender.

comments.text:

(PLA is about 10^16 Ohms resistant while an 'anti-static' object is rated at 10^12 to 10^13)

comments.text:
I am a Counselor for the Nevada Diabetic Association. Our Camp Buck starts in two weeks and I am currently printing up a couple of hundred pod covers in all different colors for each of our kids. Thank you for posting this. I know they will love them!
I encourage any one who wants to make some Diabetic kids happy, print some up and send them to your local camp or group. I added some saying and names on some pods for fun.

Let me know if you have any questions about modifying the cover, and I'd love to see what you come up with when it's done!

description.text: my house with a pool

Portraits of NASA mathematicians Dorothy Vaughan, Mary Jackson and Katherine Johnson in bas relief on the Friendship 7 capsule. The story of these African-American women’s pivotal role in the first orbit of the Earth by an American is told in the book and movie Hidden Figures.

The model is easily recognizable as a space capsule but only when it is lit from inside do these ‘hidden figures’ fully reveal themselves. This model symbolizes the invisible but vital contribution African-American women made to the early space program.
There are three version of this model.
v1 One piece model of Friendship 7 with portraits in bas relief on exterior.
v2 Two piece model of Friendship 7 with portraits in bas relief on exterior.
v3 Two piece model of Friendship 7 with portraits engraved from interior.

The appearance of the portraits with backlight (lithophane) depends on a variety of factors including scale factor, slicing settings, filament opacity and light source. Experimentation and test prints are required. These models are suitable for remixing for a variety of projects. Example photos are from the v2 model scaled at 60% for use as a nightlight.

Visit my blog http://DesignMakeTeach.com for more great designs and articles about 3D printing and making in the classroom. Or contact me on Twitter @DesignMakeTeach

Invaluable technical assistance was provided by @HoneyPoint3D https://www.honeypoint3d.com/ and @CentralScience http://www.thingiverse.com/contentbydesign/about

This model would not have been possible without the conversion of the NASA Friendship 7 3D model to STL by my good friend @Zheng3_Jim http://zheng3.com/

Sources:
Friendship 7 Model https://nasa3d.arc.nasa.gov/detail/friendship-c2
Dorothy Vaughan Portrait: https://www.nasa.gov/sites/default/files/styles/side_image/public/thumbnails/image/youngdorothyvaughan.jpeg?itok=sSWS3yi_
Mary Jackson Portrait: https://www.nasa.gov/sites/default/files/thumbnails/image/lrc-1977-b701_p-04106_0.jpg
Katherine Johnson: https://www.nasa.gov/sites/default/files/thumbnails/image/johnsonk.jpg

Reference: https://www.nasa.gov/modernfigures and https://www.nasa.gov/mission_pages/mercury/missions/friendship7.html

comments.text: What would be some good slicer settings to  use with S3D?  I have 1.75mm PLA and a 0.4mm nozzle.
comments.author: tomead

comments.text:
Start with what you normally use but before you set your printer in motion, inspect the GCODE file using some sort of visualiser, layer by layer to make sure that you have enough plastic in the areas where the faces begin and end. You need an infill setting which will give you more or less solid layers at this point. In addition to infill, you may need to adjust width over height settings to ensure that the body of the model isn't hollow - that your slicer is able to fill the gaps between the outer and inner wall.
It is all about experimentation - as said, use a visualiser program to view the GCODE before you start printing otherwise you could end up with a lot of waste although saying that the models will print quite well with standard settings. (V3 gives better results than V2 in my view).

description.text:
[WIP]

Basic mount for e3d v6.

NOTE: Thanks to Ray (un: ray4510) for the 'blank sled'

UPDATE [2017-01-24 9:15PM ET] Uploaded new files for both parts separately. The clamp fits better and has inset holes for the screws (the ones from the stock hotend will work here)

UPDATE [2017-01-25 7:49pm ET] Replaced the stl for the 'clamp' because i noticed it was not laying flat.

EDIT: [2017-06-07] I've changed to a different fan mount that is adjustable if you wanted to use the same one but switch to the volcano for e3d v6: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2120906

UPDATE [2017-08-05] Added a dual extruder version. NOTE: I have printed this but do not run dual extruders so I can't say for sure its 100%. There seems to be enough spacing between them though. If anyone wants to give it a shot and be test subject that would be awesome.

title: MP Select Mini Glass Bed Mounting Bracket

description.text:
UPDATE: Glass thicknesses vary, as do bed sizes and other variables, including different production runs of the Mini Select. This design might need to be modified for your machine, bed and glass. Please keep that in mind.

I wanted an easy to remove, yet secure mount for the borosilicate glass bed on my MP Select Mini equipped with the 4th Dimension Modifications 120x250mm extended bed. I had the borosilicate glass custom cut to a size of 5 1/8" x 10 1/8".

The brackets should also work for a standard bed equipped with a 130x130mm glass bed, although you might have to mod it a bit to adjust spacing.

It is designed to use 4 standard mini binder clips to clamp the bracket to the bed from the ends, where there should be no interference with the tower, unlike side mounted binder clips. There is also clearance for the adjustment screws as well.

I would print this with at least 50% infill as the binder clips do compress the plastic quite a bit.

** UPDATE ***
Although the original design is working fine with my MP Select Mini, it has been reported that when the printer homes at the start of a print, the print head hangs on the left front corner. I have created a modified version of the original that eliminates the corner hold downs and moves to a smaller center pressure bar. It will be slightly less secure than the original, but should eliminate any possibility of interference. Look for the V2 file.

comments.text: Quick question: The width of the bed on my MPSM is 130mm.  The mounting bracket  came out at 133.5mm width so there is no way for the end tabs to grip the bed.  Is this part for another bed?
comments.author: ccpetersen1

comments.text: As I stated in the details section, I added the borosilicate glass to my Fourth Dimension Modifications (4DM) Maximus extended bed, so yes, this is not intended for the stock bed, however the design could be easily modified in TinkerCAD to adjust the dimension.

description.text: This thing inverts a parametric torus curve under sphere inversion to tie a knot. Sphere inversion is a way to transform a 3 dimensional object that can be parameterized. Have fun!

We created this box to store our coin money. This box is inspired by this file : http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:32105 . We changed the size, shape and artwork to fit our specifications. The main changes are in the legs of the box and the opening and closing hinges. We used the laser cuter to cut the multiplex (5mm). In order to make the box We created a illustrator file at 300 DPI. We used the laser cutter at 100% power , 40% speed. To engrave the text we make a little mistake. The filled engrave created with 30% power at 40% speed and the outline engraving at a 13% power , 40 speed. Thatâs why we needed to give it a second pass. Once we were finished we simply glued it together using wood glue
print, glue and enjoy

update: the photo and rendering are out of date, I have moved the cooling nozzle for the hot end so it point more directly at the fins and more centred

After recently upgrading my Hotend to the Ubis 13S I found I was in need of a new blower fan Shroud.

The Ubis 13S says it is optional to fit a cooling fan, so I thought I would incorporate hot end cooling into the shroud.

My new shroud design has an inner duct that channels some of the air from the 50mm blower fan to the cooling fins on the hot end.

Additionally a small indent has been added to the shrouds main opening to accomodate the larger hot end.

description.text:
Update 2017-01-27:
I found my PLA prints of this thing leaked. This was due to the fact I had the air vents too close to where the coffee would be flowing. I made some changes to hopefully give some more material to prevent the leaks. Also, I printed with 4 shells vs. 2 previously. I also printed in HIPS vs. PLA. Ultimately, I want to do Acetone vapor polishing of the funnel.

The other problem I noticed is the filter could blow out through the bottom while there was liquid in the filter. That was because there wasn't anything holding it up. The latest model has 5 bars across the bottom to support the coffee filter. This also means that you will have to print with support, unfortunately.

The first article I have printed seems to work perfectly. I am printing a second unit as I need two of them.

I didn't state it previously but the cold brew pitcher I am using is this one:
https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B00FFLY64U/ref=oh_aui_detailpage_o00_s00?ie=UTF8&psc=1

This is a great item but it does let some grit out. I have found this grit gives me heartburn and detracts from the taste of the cold brew.

Original post:
This is an extension of my other cold brew coffee funnels. I made this one to filter my cold brew coffee using standard #2 coffee filters. This sits on top of a standard water bottle. No support needed. I printed mine in PLA. Food grade PETG would be good.

This was designed in Onshape. The design is here:
https://cad.onshape.com/documents/87bdb2eb9da751397fa0e9e8/w/52f99457f5fcb504699d793e/e/604495b1e8d537720516f9ec

description.text:
Last year I decided to make my own Christmas bonbons instead of forking out money for what is essentially rubbish. The toy component of my bonbon was this rubber band gun.

The gun was designed to dismantle in order to fit inside the cardboard tube and when assembled, be operable by my then 18 month old son. In keeping with the simple theme, it's a manual-load, single fire affair.

The gun is assembled trigger first into the body from the underside and then the handle to keep it together.

It's designed to work with small No.14 (50x1.5mm) rubber bands.

Printer Brand:

Formlabs

Printer:

Formlabs Form 1

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.1mm

Notes:

This rubber band gun was design to be printed on a SLA printer, so the clearances between parts may not suit FDM printing. Let me know if you attempt to print this with an FDM printer and the clearances need to be adjusted.

comments.text: I printed this on a small hand built Ultimaker clone and it works fairly well. Need to orient the parts correctly and use support in some places, but it totally works on FFF printers. If I had better nozzle cooling would have turned out a bit better fitting.

title: DrawingBot with improved head and rotate pen (for fountain pen)
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Based on DrawingBot by MakerC, with 5 new 3D/STL files that you can use to add improved slider stability for the head, including pen-tilt. You can set the rotation in 3 variations (straight / 25 degrees / 50 degrees).

In this build I've used a servo (MC-375DD), which has a slightly longer shaft section.
https://youtu.be/-gbldp3gtTE

Parts used to build:

  • 2x stepper motors (SY42STH47-1684A)
  • 1x Arduino Uno board with Arduino CNC shield
  • 2x Pololu A4988 stepper driver (with jumpers @ 4x microstepping)
  • GT2 timing belt (2 meter) + 2x GT2 20 teeth
  • 4x Micro switches on all axis (used as normally open)
  • 1x Servo motor: Modelcraft MC-375DD
    [http://www.conrad.be/ce/nl/product/275490/Digitale-micro-servo-Torque-48V]
  • Spring (custom), this gives just enough force to put pressure on the pen on the paper/surface (like with actual writing by your hand)
  • All other screws/parts/rods/bearings as listed in the original thing

Arduino code: (compiled and uploaded using the Arduino IDE; make sure to update config.h in your /Arduino/libraries/grbl folder to enable CoreXY !!!)
[More info on CoreXY here: http://corexy.com/theory.html]

  • Grbl Arduino firmware 0.9j (with stepper support) --> Use Gcode command M03 S050 to tilt the servo to release the pen; Use Gcode command M5 to raise the pen.
    [https://github.com/robottini/grbl-servo]

  • Inkscape to draw/import/convert and generate Gcode files (from extensions menu)
    [https://inkscape.org/en/]

  • Sourcerabbit Gcode sender to talk to the plotter
    [https://www.sourcerabbit.com/GCode-Sender/]

Next STL upgrade to come: carrier that can rotate and lock for a fountain pen (45c angle)

Stuck? Just send me a message if you have any question about this build!
Bracket assembly with pen rotate (4 parts)

description.header: Specific instruction using Inkscape and gcode export
description.text:
How to export to a gcode file in Inkscape

In order to do a successful export to a gcode file that you can send with a gcode-sender-tool (application) I do the following steps in Inkscape:

1) Draw or import something in inkscape

2) Make sure the drawings consist of paths/vectors (not pixels; else they can't be translated into gcode instructions). Else use the 'path' menu to convert your selections in the drawing to a path (first options: 'Object to path' or 'Stroke to path'

3) Go to menu 'extensions' --> 'gcodetools' --> choose 'Tools library'

4) In the dialog, select 'default' as 'Tools type'. Then click 'Apply'.
A green box appears now in your drawing. Click 'Close' to close the dialog.

5) Move the green box to the side of your drawing area with your mouse. Now you can edit the values in this green box, as these are the 'parameters' for your gcode export action later on.
You can experiment with the speed parameters like 'feed', 'penetration feed', 'passing feed' and 'fine feed'. It use most of them at 2000.
Double click the values to edit them (or use the text edit tool) in Inkscape (the green box is actually a grouped item with a distinct name in your drawing).

6) Now change the value '(None)' for 'gcode before path' to 'M3 050' and change '(None') for 'gcode after path' to 'M5'.
This tells the export later on to add these commands for 'lower pen' and 'raise pen' pre and post your path.

7) I use a value for 'penetration feed' like 50 to introduce a certain delay for the plotter software to 'think' is it lowering the tool head. As the command M3/M5 are without a delay so the plotter directly continues moving X/Y while the servo for the pen is still doing its move.

8) Now either select the drawing object in Inkscape you want to export to a gcode file or leave everything unselected (if you want ALL to be exported).

9) Use the menu to open 'Tools' --> 'gcodetools' --> 'Orientation points'. This will allow to us to 'calibrate' the drawing size vs what the plotter will do on a real piece of paper.
Leave the settings as they are (you can change to your linking of course). I use 2 points-mode most of the times.
Click 'Apply'. Then click 'Close' to close the dialog.

10) Now two markers have been added (as a separate named object being grouped) to your drawing.
You can open the group by double clicking one of the markers or their coordinate text. After that you should be able to select only one of the markers individually.
Leave the 0.0,0.0,0.0 marker as it is (it is in the corner of your sheet). Move the other marker (100.0,0.0,-1.0) to the correct position according to your sheet. You can do this also by typing '100' in the X-box on the top bar to move it directly to 10cm on the horizontal axis.
This is a crucial step to make sure the scale in Inkscape matches to how your gcode will get exported in the next step. So 10cm in your drawing is actually 10cm in the real world with your plotter.

(make sure your Grbl plotter settings for steps per mm X and Y are also set correctly; with 1/4 microstepping this is probably around 30)

11) Use the menu to open 'Tools' --> 'gcodetools' --> 'Path to Gcode'
You can change the 'Cutting order' setting to your liking, in most cases 'subpath by subpath' is just fine.
In the 'Preferences' tab of the dialog choose your filename/path in the 'File' and 'Directory' box.
Now make sure the first tab 'Path to Gcode' is selected/active and press the dialog button 'Apply'.
This will give a popup, press OK if that happens. Now this should generate an overlay of all your paths in your drawing with arrow and blue/green markings. That is good.
Thus, the gcode export file is created.

Press 'Close' to close the dialog.

If you want, you can delete the 'overlay' on your drawing by selecting them and press the 'delete' key on your keyboard.

I did the above instruction with a 'Spiral' being drawn on my inkscape document and this is the resulted gcode file (excluding the '-------------' rows):

%
(Header)
(Generated by gcodetools from Inkscape.)
(Using default header. To add your own header create file "header" in the output dir.)
M3
(Header end.)
G21 (All units in mm)

(Start cutting path id: path3680)
(Change tool to Default tool)

G00 Z1.000000
G00 X75.044960 Y77.679670
M3 S040
G01 Z-1.000000 F100.0(Penetrate)
G02 X73.582637 Y73.540866 Z-1.000000 I-2.216997 J-1.544427 F400.000000
G02 X69.438316 Y73.773910 Z-1.000000 I-1.741969 J5.988446

G02 X98.591733 Y71.963585 Z-1.000000 I-14.713436 J-15.691821
G02 X90.667992 Y55.253100 Z-1.000000 I-26.043697 J2.115470

comments.text:
The wobble when the arms are reaching out to their maximum could be caused by not having a rigid construction between the 2 legs (make sure to use 2 rods and one screw rod of M8 at least and tighten that one with nuts on both ends (2x2 nuts).
Another solutions it to reduce the travel of the pen lifting servo.
You will always face a little bit of wobble, but with both tricks above you should be able to reduce it!
comments.author: faisalbelwadi

comments.text:
If you suffer from a wobble on the Y-axis (which holds the pen) when the pen moves up/down rapidly, I'd suggest to first assure the base stands are joined as solid/tight as possible by using a 8mm rod and nuts with locker rings.
Also make sure the slider rods are a snug fit on both ends.
When in doubt, use else 2 or 3 rods on the bottom area by drilling those extra needed holes.

remixed_from.author: polpetras
remixed_from.title: Ciclop cut top and bottom pieces camera holder

title: Middle section of Ciclop camera holder

description.text:
This is a remix of https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1613839 which is in turn a remix of https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:740357.

The first thing cuts a big camera holder part into tree pieces for easier printing on small beds but only provides the top and bottom sections.

This thing is the missing mid section.

The original part appears to have been cut at Y=-50mm and Y=37.5mm

I grabbed the original STL and tried to cut the mid part between those planes. I knew very little about the mesh manipulation tools so it took me a while to find a way to do it. Detailsfor posterity:

  • OpenSCAD: almost worked but I was getting annoying assertion error on final export. Could not fix it and gave up.
  • FreeCAD: could not find a way to close the top/bottom of the mesh after cutting it with planes.
  • Meshlab: almost worked; I produced the mid section by diffing the original part and the union of outer hulls (produced by OpenSCAD) of the top and bottom sections. The mid section was merged with some tiny diff artifacts left from the top and the bottom parts. With those artifacts the part was still too big for my print bed. I could split it into connected components and clean it up, but I found a simpler Blender based solution sooner.
  • Blender: finally, I produced the part in Blender. Its UI is overwhelming, but I managed to subtract two carefully placed cubes from the original part. Yay!

Un Porte Crayons spécifique aux bureaux inclinés. Le système "auto nivelage" permet à la boite de rester toujours stable et droite, peu importe le degré d'inclinaison. Il est équipé d'un tiroir aimanté. Les 2 supports permettant le pivot possèdent des aimants car certains bureaux possèdent un plateau métallique, pour ceux qui ne le sont pas, il y a deux supports supplémentaires permettant de fixer l'ensemble sur la partie supérieure du bureau.

J'ai fabriqué ces outils pour aider mon fils qui est DYSPRAXIQUE, il travaille sur ce genre de bureau mais ne possède pas de matériel adapté et il n'existe malheureusement pas beaucoup d'outils pour les aider.

J'invite tous les Maker à aider les enfants ou personnes handicapés.

A specific pen holder for sloping desks. The self-leveling system allows the box to remain stable and straight, regardless of the degree of inclination. It is equipped with a magnetic drawer. The two supports allowing the pivot have magnets because some offices have a metal plate, for those that are not, there are two additional supports allowing to fix the whole on the top of the desk.

I have made these tools to help my son who is DYSPRAXIQUE, he works on this kind of office but has no suitable equipment and unfortunately there is not much tool to help them.

I invite all makers to help children or people with disabilities.

title: E3D V6 40mm Fan Snap on with Zip tie tabs

description.text:
Based on loco's E3d v6 40mm Fan Duct

I modified the model to be snap on, even in PLA, as well as adding zip tie tabs to be used either to more securely mount the fan duct, for wire management, or anything else.

Caution: I have yet to test how durable the PLA is over the course of time, but if I have problems, I will report back. However, even with the hot end facing towards the front, the shroud should not touch it, so direct melting shouldn't be an issue.

If the shroud fails to slide on, be sure lip is riding the top fin of the heatsink. Failing that, try flipping it over the other way. Snapped right on with my Hatchbox PLA, but if your PLA is too crispy and brittle, it may fail. Tight fit, so may need a well calibrated printer. If the print is still too tight horizontally, scale up to 1.01x.

May need supports if you want the zip tie bridge to look pretty, but it is thick enough so a little sagging shouldn't matter. Also, I arched the bridge to minimize sagging, so I wouldn't even worry about supports unless you are OCD about those things.

Edit: Improved the model so that the zip tie tabs are more rounded and look nicer, and tapered the lip so that installation is easier when using stiff/brittle filaments.

Monoprice Select Mini

100%

author: rich1051414

title: Aurora A3 E3D V6 + MK8 Bowden mounts

description.text:
NOTE:This is a Work in Progress - That May Never Get Completed! I print all my prototypes in Gray, so you can see, this never got past the prototype stage.

I designed and printed this and then had so many problems with cheap Chinese E3D v6 knockoffs jamming that I gave up. Now my A3 is dialed in nicely with the stock MK8 that I don't feel the need for a E3Dv6/Bowden extruder combo anymore.

I did print this, as the photos show. I did fit this to my printer. It does fit. And the E3D mount aligns correctly to the stock X-Axis carriage (with one extra screw). Everything SHOULD work, but I never got a chance to test it.

As the photos show, this is setup for dual cooling fans. The fan size is the same as the stock nozzle cooling fan that comes with the A3. I print with PLA almost exclusively and believe the quicker you can cool it down after extruding, the better: less droops/oozing/warping.

The MK8 mount for the Bowden configuration is a bit odd. I have my spool mounted to the back/right side of the A3 and so the MK8 mount is aligned to feed the filament from there (see photo). You will also need to rotate the extruder on the motor 90 degrees to fit properly in the mount. There is no room for the extruder cooling fan - I don't believe you need one since it will be far away from the hot-end.

All told this will reduce the weight on your X-Axis by about 60% - theoretically allowing faster printing/traveling/jerking/acceleration without causing those nasty ripples in the prints.

But, like I said, I never got around to testing it.

ALSO! This will raise the nozzle up from the bed about 4mm. This is intentional. I did this because the bed, by default, is mashed too close to the Y-Axis carriage plate thus not giving any room to add PrintBite or any other special print adhesion material.

I've included the original Sketchup files in case anyone wants to modify it to make it work for their installation. If you need a different file format, I might be able to help. If you have any questions, let me know. If you need me to modify any of the objects, I cannot help. I got too much on my plate right now for custom work. Sorry.

Printer:

JG Aurora A3 Prusa I3

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.2mm

Infill:

20%

Notes:

Still want to print this? OK!

I printed this in PLA, but since I never have thoroughly tested it, I'm not sure how it will hold up against the heat generated from the E3Dv6. You may want to consider PETG or (gasp) ABS.

The fan duct walls are only .5mm thick to keep it as light as possible - so they are just single walls basically. Everything else can be printed however you wish for strength and durability.
Print all objects as oriented and your should not need any supports - just a little drooping clean up here and there.

Additional Hardware

To mount the E3Dv6 mount to the X-Axis carriage, you'll need one extra screw (4) than the stock mount (3). Mine came with an extra one...

All other hardware screws are standard M3 nuts and bolts and there are sockets in the E3Dv6 mount to hold all the nuts in place. It's designed for two cooling fans, so you'll need to get another one and splice the wires together.

Note in the photo how the E3Dv6 hotend is placed in the mounting: its fan is in the front and the heater coil is in front of the nozzle. You'll want to mount it that way of you're going to use the dual fan duct.

Notes:

La pieza está pensada para poder imprimirla en una impresora de FDM "casera" sin ningún problema en especial salvo que tiene mucha zona de contacto con la superficie.

Impresora: Prusa i3
Rafts: No necesita, pero si no quieres que se contraiga nada por los bordes sí sería interesante
Soporte: No necesita ningún tipo de soporte

Relleno: Mejor rellenar al 100% para que tenga la mayor resistencia posible en el menor volumen.

Estas piezas se diseñaron para evitar que Celia saque los pies de la silla de ruedas y se haga daño.
A partir de unas plantillas dibujadas en una servilleta por su madre, y utilizando el mismo sistema que las férulas "Cock Splint" ferula cock up splint

La pieza está pensada para poder imprimirla en una impresora de FDM "casera" sin ningún problema en especial salvo que tiene mucha zona de contacto con la superficie.

Soporte: No necesita ningún tipo de soporte

Para adaptar la pieza al usuario final hay que moldearla con agua caliente (a unos 100º es suficiente)

title: Tank3D E3D V6 Fan 3010 LayerFan 5015 Probe M8x1 Probe M12x1

description.text:
HI there,

I felt the need to draw and redesign from zero all around the hotend for my new printer.

So i share here with you a complete solution for the E3D V6, Volcano and their clones.

While its inspired from others work, i had to think it out and do it again because of small errors i found, adjust volume and direction output of layer fan, not rigid and sturdy to my liking and most of all because all designs do not permit exchanging the heater to Volcano and the so necessary correction of the nozzle of the blower fan height.

Another reason was the inductive probe. Most popular Inductive probes, and cheapest are M12X1 threads. The best if you like to be light weight is M8x1 proximity sensor Threads are real M8x1 and 12x1 on drawing and the split is so its easy to fit. Possibly you will not need thread locker as the fit is tight.

If you need some size adjustment , different probe thread or whatever, just tell me so, i will correct it.

Part of Tank3d Printer , many more things there, take a look.

CREDITS:
If somebody feels i should give him credit please say so in PM. I am not aware who originally came with the idea of this type of solution.

Credits go to Aleksandr Ivanov for sharing the CAD model of Radial Cooling 5015 Fan (50mm)

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

best

Infill:

50%

Notes:

Must be temp resistant plastic. Hi temp PLA, ABS, PTEG, etc. Possibly will work even normal PLA but not advised, especially as its a part of a printer thats meant to be enclosed.

My rule is not to save 2g of plastic on critical components

title: Crane
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This is a project that my Kids and I did over the school holidays. we have designed and printed it. It is our interpretation of all the cranes we see in our local area putting up multi story units where there was once period homes.

I have included the original 123 Design file and STl's. I have cleaned up and reduced the number of STL's. it has been laid out to print on a 250mm x 250mm bed.

A little filing and sanding may be required to get a neat fit on the parts.

The only part glued on in our example is the pin that holds the base to the tower.

3X3mm magnets were used on the hook so the kids could easily change them over.

On our example we have included 8 segments in the base, but have only included one in the STL's.

Ours Stands 1000mm to the top of the boom as shown in the photos

author: Mafo

description.text:
This is a spool holder I designed for the TEVO Tarantula but could be used with any other printer with the similar type of frame. The purpose is for the spool to rotate clockwise and for the filament to come from underneath into the extruder. I have also rounded the top edge of the spool arm to reduce catching and jerking the spool while feeding out the filament. There are 2 arm widths available - one for upto 45mm spool width and another for upto 50mm wide spools.

Update: Just added a holder which is 15mm longer and has an arm width of 75mm to cater for larger spools of upto 70mm wide. It has also been strengthened to allow for the weight and size of those spools.

Used 123D Design to create the part with Repetier Host and Cura to slice it.

The part is secured by using M4 bolts with M4 washers and T-Nuts of the appropriate size with the configuration of bolt and washer through hole then T-Nut into frame.

Printing was set to :
First Layer Height : 0.35
Layer Height : 0.3mm
Print Speed : 45mm/s
Infill Density : 10%
Bed Temp : 50c
Nozzle Temp : 210c
Fan Duct installed
Printed on glass with tape

I have set the infill to 10% only as I was running very low on filament but I would of used 15% in normal situations and at 10% it works fine.

title: [idbox] Primary Extruder
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This is a direct drive bowden extruder remodeled for deagostini idbox.
It cannot be used as a secondary extruder. (Because it contacts the Y axis bearing when mounted)

Remixed from: Compact Bowden extruder by scarou
Merged from: [idbox] Filament Funnel Set, Pacman Helper Disk V2 by midniteandy

Updates

  • 2017-01-29 Added Spring_Compressor.stl
  • 2017-03-02 Added Extruder_Body_Disks_SupportV2.stl
  • 2017-12-21 Added Spring_Compressor_V2.stl and Washer_Board.stl
  • 2017-12-28 Added Spring_Compressor_V2.1.stl

Requirements

  • Use for extruder
    • 1 x Stepper motor (included in the idbox kit)
    • 1 x MK8 drive gear
      • Outer diameter: 9mm
      • Length: 11mm
      • Hob diameter: 7mm
      • Bore: 5mm
    • 1 x 625ZZ bearing (or 625-2RS bearing)
    • 1 x 608ZZ bearing (or 608-2RS bearing)
    • 2 x M3x8mm pan head screws
    • 2 x M3x10mm pan head screws
    • 2 x M3x15mm pan head screws
    • 2 x M3x40mm any screws
      If you use a spring compressor, you may choose a flat head screws.
      Truss head screws are not suitable for spring compressor.
    • 2 x Compression springs
      • Wire diameter: 0.5‒1mm (0.0197‒0.0394")
      • Outer diameter: 5‒7mm (0.1969‒0.2756")
      • Free length: 10‒15mm (0.3937‒0.5905")
    • 4 x M3 nuts (included in the idbox kit)
    • 12 x M3 washers
  • Use for mount
    • 2 x M3x14mm truss head screws (included in the idbox kit)
    • 2 x M3 nuts (included in the idbox kit)
    • 2 x M3 washers (included in the idbox kit)

Print Settings

  • Body settings
    • Resolution: 0.2mm
    • Perimeter count: 4
    • Infill: 30%
    • Rafts: Yes
    • Supports: Yes
    • Supports everywhere: No
  • Idler settings
    • Resolution: 0.2mm
    • Perimeter count: 4
    • Infill: 60% (or higher)
    • Supports: Yes
  • Bearing spacer settings
    • Resolution: 0.2mm
    • Supports: No
  • Spring compressor settings
    • Resolution: 0.2mm
    • Supports: No

Marlin Firmware Settings

  • Configuration.h

    • Invert the direction of motor rotation
      #define INVERT_E0_DIR true
    • E steps per mm
      • Hob effective diameter: 7mm
        #define DEFAULT_AXIS_STEPS_PER_UNIT {71.1111,71.1111,3200,145.5131}
      • Hob effective diameter: 6.9mm
        #define DEFAULT_AXIS_STEPS_PER_UNIT {71.1111,71.1111,3200,147.6212}
      • Hob effective diameter: 6.8mm
        #define DEFAULT_AXIS_STEPS_PER_UNIT {71.1111,71.1111,3200,149.7929}
      • Hob effective diameter: 6.7mm
        #define DEFAULT_AXIS_STEPS_PER_UNIT {71.1111,71.1111,3200,152.0286}
  • Reference
    • Triffid Hunter's Calibration Guide - RepRapWiki

      e_steps_per_mm = (motor_steps_per_rev * driver_microstep) * (big_gear_teeth / small_gear_teeth) / (hob_effective_diameter * pi)

Bearing Spacer

If the bearing spacer does not fit in the hole of the motor, polish the bearing spacer with waterproof sandpaper.

Spring Compressor

Insert the spring compressor between the screw head and the washer, you can increase the pressure on the spring.
When 3D printing is finished, pulling out the spring compressor from the screw head can reduce the burden on the idler and the spring.

Washer Board

The washer board makes it easy to insert the spring compressor.
Attach to the screw head protruding from the idler.

title: Minicraft MB1012 drill press, customizable clamps and quick release

description.text:
If you have a Dremel 3000 or 4000 then go to the original or one of the remixes, but maybe consider using my quick releases (maybe with a washer between release and clamp.) If you have a minicraft drill, or any other drill that needs different clamps, then you're probably in the right place!

I wanted a drill press for my Minicraft drill and this requires different clamps to the original. I also wanted quick releases and couldn't find any suitable ones. I have provided SCAD files for everything so people can play. I haven't added the customizer headers as I find the thingiverse customizer slow and it crashes my browser a lot so I just install OpenSCAD on my machine. Feel free to add and remix if you like!

Note that the ring can be offset relative to the base in a very flexible way, and you can even tweak the angle by changing the rotate in the code, but going over the top will leave odd gaps as the code currently is.

You'll need to add this library to your OpenSCAD libraries directory.

https://github.com/JohK/nutsnbolts

This is my first vaguely serious bit of OpenSCAD so apologies for coding "style". The Minkowski in particular is very slow so don't go thinking that OpenSCAD has crashed the first time.

Enjoy!

P.S. I have now turned my brain on and assembled the lever as shown in the close up so that the force of pulling the lever down forces it against the nylock nut. So plain nut in the handle part that attaches lever to pinion studding, then a washer and then a nylock on the outside.

Yes

0.2mm

Infill:

25%

Notes:

Supports only needed for the quick release. I used Cura's zigzag that removes very easily.

Fitting quick release bolt

The QR takes a M3 bolt with a hex head. Length depends on clamp size but 30mm plus may be required. If you cut one to size, put a couple of nuts on it first and remove/refit these to clean up the thread.

You may need to drill out one side of the clamp slightly to let the bolt move freely.

Fit the bolt to the quick release centre using the access hole in the lever part and then use a nut and washer to pull it deeper into position. You can then "twiddle" the QR as tight as you like with the last part done with the clamp held closed with fingers. Tune tension so the drill is easy to fit with the clamp open and held tight with it closed.

comments.author: s3rkan

comments.text: Designspark can be a litle tricky sometimes. A complex part, i create in separated componentes (one side duct and top in this case). Sides i made using the shell function. Create duct as a solid. When it has the expected shape, select shell, type thickness, click at side (cooler position), then click on botton. Add shape to attach cooler, drill roles. Duplicate the duct and rotate do be one at left and one at right. Then position the top section, glue all togheter and finish. But it all took me some days to accomplish and is still untested. I will make a vídeo when i have some time.

description.text:
Here I decided to use a big screw for the major friction point. I also screwed the guide in to the printer top using one of the existing LCD screws. This filament guide replaces one of the pillars for the LCD screen.

I have to use a big screw with large thread pitch, so that the 1.75 filament could go nicely without scratching.

Main drawback - you need an extra screw. I used:
Length: 37 mm (can be 12 mm less, so 25 is probably minimum)
Outer diameter: 5 mm (can probably be less, 4 mm will do I guess)
Inner diameter (thread): 3.2 mm. (Can be slightly bigger, but it will be hard to screw it in)
Large thread pitch, enough for the filament to lay comfortably between thread rings.

Pluses: I printed it without supports on Anet A8. Tiny, 3 gram only. Took 26 minutes to print with 0.2mm layer.

Printer:

Anet A8

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.4 mm / layer 0.2 mm

Infill:

20%

I tried to use the following filament guide
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1764285
It turned out to be too loose after a few prints, also filament string drilled a hole in the plastic of the guide and increased friction a lot.

I decided to used metal in my design to avoid friction and corresponding plastic drilling effect.
Case for 700TVL camera
Design with Designspark mechanical

As a result of the elevated currents which have to be managed to warm the bed, especially while working with materials such as ABS, it is highly recommendable to have a device at our disposal in order to handle all that stream and release our MB of that work. To do so, in the market ,we can find relays (mechanical and SSR), or what is known as MOSFET electronic circuit , since it is its main element .

If we focus on this second option, I suggest this mosfet I have made by taking advantage and recycling material which I already owned, and whose cost has been therefore zero for me. In any case this material may end up being really interesting and economical when working by yourself at home.

The mosfet I used, which as I have just said, is one that I had in my components drawer, although it could easily be another one, is a IRPF054, capable of handling 64A at 100 ° C continuously. The chosen transistor for the inverter is a BC547, a reference in signal amplification, so you shouldn´t find it difficult to locate.

This circuit, unlike the ones designed for commercial purposes, does require that we identify, in our card printer, the positive and negative connections to the "hot bed" , as we will need to establish the connection to the negative pin in order to get the control signal.

This doesn´t happen in the commercial ones as they use a bridge rectifier, but as I have explained, the design is the result of using material I already kept in my drawer, and the bridges I had resulted to be too large.

As for the rest of the procedure, not much complication, just plug it according to the described electrical scheme and you’ll get it ready to work.

For those of you who want to make their PCB, I have made it available in Autodesk CIRCUITS: https://circuits.io/circuits/3670338-mosfet-hot-bed/embed#schematic

If you make it, please share your photos :-).

Debido a las elevadas intensidades de corriente que es necesario manejar para calentar la cama, sobre todo cuando trabajamos con materiales como el ABS, resulta interesante disponer de un dispositivo que manejetoda esa corriente y que libere anuestra MB de ese trabajo. Para eso disponemos en el mercado de reles (mecánicos y SSR), o de ciruitos electrónicos denominados MOSFET, por ser éste su elemento protagonista.

Centrándonos en esta segunda opción, os propongo este mosfet que he realizando aprovechando y reciclando material que tenía disponible, y cuyo coste en mi caso ha sido cero, pero que en cualquier caso puede ser realmente económico e interesante para realizar uno mismo en casa.

El mosfet empleado, que como he dicho, es uno que tenía disponible en mi cajón de componentes, pero que perfectamente puede ser cualquier otro, es un IRPF054, capaz de manejar de continuo 64A a 100ºC. El transistor empleado en el inversor es un BC547, un clásico en amplificación de señal, por lo que no debéis tener problema en localizarlo.
Este circuito, a diferencia de los comerciales, sí necesita que identifiquemos en la placa de nuestra impresora el positivo y negativo de las conexiones a la "hot bed" ya que necesitaremos conectarnos al pin negativo para tomar la señal de control.
En los comerciales esto no ocurre porque utilizan un puente rectificador, pero como he dicho, el diseño es aprovechando lo que tengo en el cajón, y los puentes que tenía son demasiado grandes.

Por lo demás, poca complicación, simplemente conectarlo según el esquema eléctrico propuesto y a funcionar.

Para quien se quiera hacer su PCB, lo tengo disponible en AUTODESK CIRCUITS:

Esquema:
https://circuits.io/circuits/3670338-mosfet-hot-bed/embed#schematic

PCB:
https://circuits.io/circuits/3670338-mosfet-hot-bed/embed#pcb

Si lo haces, por favor, comparte tus fotos. Gracias.

remixed_from.title: Wireframe Skull Pencil Holder (For The Love of Dog)

description.text:
I had a lot of problems slicing the original model with Simplify 3D. There are technically a lot of errors in the original model. If you zoom in on the mesh you can see it. The S3D slicer does not work very well with this. But I also had some problems with Slic3r.

I needed some time to figure out what happens and then tried to fix the mesh using a lot of different tools and steps. The final version now passes all tests and prints very nicely. It is also scaled up to double the size of the original which was a bit small for my taste. I also made the ground plate solid and flat on both sides.

See the supplied image: The right side skull is the original sliced and printed with S3D despite of the errors. The left version is my fixed version, printed on the same printer with the same settings. The color differences is because the left one was printed with white BDP while the right version was printed with Flax BDP both by Extrudr.com.

Real print time was 10 hours.

Edit: I didn't checked it before but http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1905711 is an even better fixed version than mine! So you may want to use that one if you are going to print this!

description.text:
I designed this part to mount my Oculus sensors in the corners of my room.
I did not want to drill into the walls so I designed it to be glued onto the wall.
The mount is designed so that the mount can be glued in place and the sensor attached after the glue has hardened. I used hotglue and a gluegun for this.
For the glue to get a really good grip on the part I wanted to make sure the surfaces are rough, and I figured an easy way to do this is to engrave text into it.

The sensor friction fits very well into the mount and has enough space to be rotated and tilted in order to aim the sensor as desired.
The cable can easily be tucked into the provided cable guide which is designed so that the cable should not easily fall out of the guide under the pull of gravity.

title: Dungeon Dolls: Tiefling
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Updated 2/19/17

Ever like the variable designs of FlatMinis, but the customization of Dungeon Dolls? Ever wanted more options? Look no further! Inspired by the aesthetic of GrumpyRobot's FlatMinis, and DutchMogul's Dungeon Doll system, come Trixster_98's take on the classic Dungeon Doll.

This handy Tiefling includes a demonic wand, plain pants, shirt with chain and spiky pauldrons, a set of wicked horns, and a cape base if you wish or a plain base if not.I printed mine at 200% (Red) and the base stands at 56 mm tall. You can also print at 150% (Grey) which stands at 42 mm. Fully customizable and modular, look for more designs to come in the following weeks.

These designs are fully compatible with DutchMogul's original Dungeon Dolls, but not with FlatMinis
Made in Tinkercad, red printed at my library, grey printed on my Monoprice MP Select Mini
The remixed and improved version of my 2014 work that was unprintable and abandoned shortly after inception

Printing
The pieces should be printed at 150-200% depending on what you feel your printers accuracy to be. My printer can make all the details clearly visible at 100% but needs the print to be at 150% in order to fit together well.
The picture shows the 3 sizes of 200%, 150%, and 100%

Preparation
In order for the pieces to properly fit together, you will need to lightly sand them with a set of needle files. The heads just need very minute sanding in the eye holes. My first layer is always slightly off which always needs work in that one spot. The studs that attach to the shirt and pants need light sanding, but the holes should be fine, depending on your printers accuracy. The shirt stud typically needs a very small amount of sanding compared to the pant studs. The bottom that fits onto the base will most likely need sanding on both the hole and stud depending on accuracy.

Always test fit pieces together as you sand. I'm not responsible for ruined pieces due to too much sanding.

author: mikifly

title: Y Axis Tensioner Idler (CTC, Geetech, Pro B)

description.text:
Details

This is a front panel Y tensioner to replace that found in GEETech and CTC Ebay Kit Printers.

The default one that comes with these printers has an infill of about 5-10% and mine snapped so after a few hours hacking together a temporary y axis idler / tensioner i was able to get my printer to print a new one that i designed in autodesk 123d.

Printer now works perfectly and the part has been upgraded to have slightly thicker walls.

Print this with as much extra infill as you want, ideally 100% for the ultimate strength but 50% will work fine :)

I have added a photo of my printer so you can see the type that this part goes with, it may work for yours but i was unable to find ANY that fit my printer (it was just a kit from ebay)

update: I've split the top half of this into a separate piece and added alignment pins, this will allow you to print it in two halves assemble the y idle gears inside the piece and then super glue it together. This is more like how the in-box piece from the kit works when it is assembled at the factory.

Social

If your interested in 3D printing I make videos about my own 3D printing escapades on youtube including upgrade tutorials, mods, and other misc stuff.
http://www.youtube.com/rm2kdev

you can also find me at
http://www.twitter.com/rm2kdev

Printer:

Prusa I3 Style

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.1mm

Infill:

50%

May Need Filing

Depending on the accuracy of your printer this part may need some basic filing and cleaning up since we are dealing with fairly tight tolerances if your printer cant print to exact or very close to exact measurements then you may need to file down a bit here and a bit there to get it working nicely :)

comments.text: I have this printer, and I have this broken part, I agree with the comments about the quality of the part.  I'm grateful for you making this available. The difficulty with this part is fitting the combination of bearings, pulley and shaft into a single piece of plastic without moving the pulley on the shaft. Splitting the piece in two is a good idea. But in the current design there is a non-supported area (I was surprised it printed as well as it did, but it is not right). I also had misgivings about the holes into which the bearings go, being cut on a chord not a diameter - but I was wrong, the bearings snapped in nicely. My broken part is on the X axis, and I also need a rounded back to fit the main X-idler.
comments.author: DavidPilling

comments.text: well in the end i am glad it was able to help :) you are right about it not supporting all the variants of bearings and plastic sizes and shapes etc this was really just something i made in an emergency to get my own printer up and running the sizes and shapes are things that came from the kit i assembled and i figured that since many people buy the same kits this issue might pop up for someone else :P

description.text: I didn't like the way the Oculus Touch controllers rolled around on my desk so I found and modified these hands. All I did was add a base. Please note that I have only included the left hand and you will have to use your software to mirror the model if you want the right hand. I've also found that both touch controllers fit well on one hand as well.

Printer Brand:

LulzBot

Printer:

TAZ 6

Rafts:

No

Yes

0.010

30

Notes:

Here are my print specifics:

  • Printed using a Lulzbot Taz 6
  • I used Verbatim PLA
  • Used basic CURA settings for standard print. 0.010 layers I believe, infill 30%.
  • Printed with supports
  • No post processing on model

Remix of wine hand

No real design here. I just imported the original wine hand and added a base in Inventor.
